title: 114_s2508
content: The Act may be cited as the "Youth Sports Concussion Act". It includes findings and the sense of Congress. The "Youth Sports Concussion Act" highlights Congress's findings on the importance of scientific advancements in reducing sports-related concussions in youth. The National Academies' 2013 report emphasized the need for research on biomechanical factors influencing injury risk. Congress also urges the Consumer Product Safety Commission to review relevant research in this area. The National Academies recommend research on biomechanical factors influencing injury risk in youth sports concussions. The Federal Trade Commission should review this research to protect consumers from unfair practices in commerce. SEC. 3. FALSE OR MISLEADING CLAIMS WITH RESPECT TO ATHLETIC SPORTING ACTIVITY EQUIPMENT. It is illegal to sell or import athletic equipment with deceptive safety claims in interstate commerce. Violations will be treated as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The FTC has enforcement powers in such cases. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this section using the same powers and regulations as outlined in the Federal Trade Commission Act. Violators will face penalties and entitled privileges and immunities. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this section with penalties and privileges as outlined in the Federal Trade Commission Act. States can also enforce this section if residents are affected by violations. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action on behalf of residents in federal court to obtain injunctive relief for violations. Before initiating the action, the attorney general must notify the Federal Trade Commission in writing. The attorney general of a State must provide a copy of the complaint before filing a civil action. If not feasible, they must notify the Federal Trade Commission immediately upon initiating the action. The FTC can intervene in civil actions brought by state attorneys general. The attorney general of a State can intervene in civil actions and file petitions for appeal. The attorney general also has investigatory powers to conduct investigations and compel witnesses or evidence. If the Federal Trade Commission takes action for a violation, the attorney general can still proceed with their civil action. The attorney general of a State may not bring a civil action against a defendant named in a complaint by the Commission during the pendency of the Commission's action. Venue for such actions can be in any district court in the United States, and process can be served in any district where the defendant is an inhabitant or can be found. Actions by other state officials may bring civil actions under the same requirements and limitations as attorneys general.
